com.jidesoft.docking
Interface DockingManager

All Superinterfaces:
LayoutPersistence
All Known Implementing Classes:
DefaultDockingManager
public interface DockingManager
extends LayoutPersistence

DockingManager is an interface that has a bunch of methods which managers DockableFrames.

It usually has following functions.

  • Add, remove, show, hide, activate, deactivate, and autohide DockableFrames.
  • Save/load layout information to/from a persistent storage.
  • Interactive with user allowing user to drag, dock, float, hide, or resize all Dockable or DragableDockable.

      See Also:
      DefaultDockingManager, DockableFrame

      SPLIT_EAST_WEST_SOUTH_NORTH

      public static final int SPLIT_EAST_WEST_SOUTH_NORTH
      This is used by setInitSplitPriority method. In this value is used, we will split the whole window in the order of east, west, south and north.

      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

      SPLIT_SOUTH_NORTH_EAST_WEST

      public static final int SPLIT_SOUTH_NORTH_EAST_WEST
      This is used by setInitSplitPriority method. In this value is used, we will split the whole window in the order of south, north, east and west.

      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

      beginDraggingFrame

      public void beginDraggingFrame(javax.swing.JComponent f,
                               int mouseX,
                               int mouseY,
                               double relativeX,
                               double relativeY,
                               boolean single)
      This method is normally called when the user has indicated that they will begin dragging a component around. This method should be called prior to any dragFrame() calls to allow the DockingManager to prepare. Normally f will be a DockableFrame.

      Parameters:
      f - a component to be dragged
      mouseX - mouse screen location on X direction
      mouseY - mouse screen location on Y direction
      relativeX - percentage location of mouse to the component on X direction
      relativeY - percentage location of mouse to the component on Y direction
      single - drag just one frame or all frames in tabs

      dragFrame

      public void dragFrame(javax.swing.JComponent f,
                      int newX,
                      int newY,
                      int mouseModifiers)
      The user has moved the frame. Calls to this method will be preceded by calls to beginDraggingFrame(). Normally f will be a DockableFrame.

      Parameters:
      f - component to be dragged
      newX - new mouse location on X direction
      newY - new mouse location on Y direction
      mouseModifiers - mouse modifiers from MouseEvent when dragging

      pauseDragFrame

      public void pauseDragFrame()
      Pause the dragging session of a frame. It simply hide any indication of it's being dragging. dragFrame will automatically resume the dragging session.

      endDraggingFrame

      public void endDraggingFrame(javax.swing.JComponent f)
      This method signals the end of the dragging session. Any state maintained by the DockingManager can be removed here. Normally f will be a DockableFrame.

      isDragging

      public boolean isDragging()
      Check if there is a dragging going on.

      Returns:
      true if dragging.

      cancelDragging

      public void cancelDragging()
      Cancel the dragging.

      beginResizingFrame

      public void beginResizingFrame(javax.swing.JComponent f,
                               int direction)
      This methods is normally called when the user has indicated that they will begin resizing the frame. This method should be called prior to any resizeFrame() calls to allow the DockingManager to prepare. Normally f will be a DockableFrame.

      resizingFrame

      public void resizingFrame(javax.swing.JComponent f,
                          int newX,
                          int newY,
                          int newWidth,
                          int newHeight)
      The user has resized the component. Calls to this method will be preceded by calls to beginResizingFrame(). Normally f will be a DockableFrame.

      endResizingFrame

      public void endResizingFrame(javax.swing.JComponent f)
      This method signals the end of the resize session. Any state maintained by the DockingManager can be removed here. Normally f will be a DockableFrame.

      getRootPaneContainer

      public javax.swing.RootPaneContainer getRootPaneContainer()
      Gets root pane container. Root pane container is the JFrame, JWindow, JDialog or JApplet where this manager is installed to.

      Returns:
      root pane container

      getMainFrame

      public javax.swing.JFrame getMainFrame()
      Deprecated. use getRootPaneContainer instead since DockingManager can support all RootPaneContainer, not just JFrame

      Gets the main JFrame.

      Returns:
      main JFrame

      getDockedFrameContainer

      public com.jidesoft.docking.DockedFrameContainer getDockedFrameContainer()
      Gets the main container. Main container is the container that contains all docked window within the main frame. It doesn't include side bars, doesn't include toolbar or menu bar.

      Returns:
      main container

      getWorkspace

      public Workspace getWorkspace()
      Gets workspace. Workspace is the area in the middle of the main frame that can used as the main workspace for documents for example.

      Returns:
      workspace

      showWorkspace

      public void showWorkspace()
      Shows workspace area.

      hideWorkspace

      public void hideWorkspace()
      hide workspace area.

      toggleState

      public void toggleState(DockableFrame frame,
                        boolean single)
      Toggle the frame's state. If it's docked, change to floating mode; if floating, change to docked mode.

      Parameters:
      frame - the frame to change mode
      single - change mode for all frames in the same tabbed pane or just the frame itself.

      getSelectedFrame

      public DockableFrame getSelectedFrame()
      Deprecated. replaced by getActiveFrame(). This is nothing with this method. It's just the two terms - selected frame v.s. active frame - confused users. As the dockable frame event uses active and deactive, it makes more sense to use active frame.

      Gets currently selected frame.

      Returns:
      currently selected frame

      getActiveFrame

      public DockableFrame getActiveFrame()
      Gets currently selected frame.

      Returns:
      currently selected frame

      getInitSplitPriority

      public int getInitSplitPriority()
      Gets the initial split priority. Possible values are SPLIT_EAST_WEST_SOUTH_NORTH, SPLIT_SOUTH_NORTH_EAST_WEST. The direction in front has a high priority than those after it. For example, if you initially has two frames, the initial side of one is south and the other one is east. If you use SPLIT_EAST_WEST_SOUTH_NORTH, the east one will cover the whole east side and the south one will cover whatever left. However if you use SPLIT_SOUTH_NORTH_EAST_WEST, the south one will cover the whole south side and the east one will cover whatever left.

      Returns:
      split priority.

      setInitSplitPriority

      public void setInitSplitPriority(int initSplitPriority)
      Sets the initial split priority. Valid values are SPLIT_EAST_WEST_SOUTH_NORTH, SPLIT_SOUTH_NORTH_EAST_WEST. The direction in front has a high priority than those after it. For example, if you initially has two frames, the initial side of one is south and the other one is east. If you use SPLIT_EAST_WEST_SOUTH_NORTH, the east one will cover the whole east side and the south one will cover whatever left. However if you use SPLIT_SOUTH_NORTH_EAST_WEST, the south one will cover the whole south side and the east one will cover whatever left.

      Parameters:
      initSplitPriority - split priority.

      getInitDelay

      public int getInitDelay()
      Gets the initial delay.

      Returns:
      the initial delay

      getInitCenterSplit

      public int getInitCenterSplit()
      Gets the initial center split. During initial layout, assuming there are several dockable frames' initSide are DOCK_SIDE_CENTER. Among them, the ones with the same index will be put into the same tabbed pane. If they have different index, they will be put into a multple split pane. This flag will control the orientation of the split pane.

      Returns:
      the orientation of initial split pane in the center.

      setInitCenterSplit

      public void setInitCenterSplit(int initCenterSplit)
      Sets the initial center split.

      Parameters:
      initCenterSplit -
      See Also:
      getInitCenterSplit()

This flag will control the orientation of the split pane.

      Returns:
      the orientation of initial split pane in the east.

      isTabDockAllowed

      public boolean isTabDockAllowed()

      setTabDockAllowed

      public void setTabDockAllowed(boolean allowed)
      Sets the attribute if tab docking is allowed. If the flag is false, user will not be able to tab dock to dockable frame together. However this flag wouldn't affect initial state. If you don't want any tab dock during initialization, you need to make sure dockable frames on the same init side to have different init index.

      Parameters:
      allowed -

      isNestedFloatingAllowed

      public boolean isNestedFloatingAllowed()
      Checks if nest floating frames are allowed. If this flag is false, when you drag something over a floating frame, nothing will happen just like the floating frame doesn't exist. If this flag is true, you can drag a frame over a floating frame and the outline will change shape to indicate where it will be dropped just like other frames in the main JFrame.

      Returns:
      true if it's allowed. Otherwise, false

      setNestedFloatingAllowed

      public void setNestedFloatingAllowed(boolean nestedFloatingAllowed)
      Sets if allows nested floating frames.

      Parameters:
      nestedFloatingAllowed -
      See Also:
      isNestedFloatingAllowed()

      isDragAllTabs

      public boolean isDragAllTabs()
      Checks if draging the title bar will drag all the dockable frames in that tabbed pane. By default draggin the title bar of a dockable frame will drag all dockable frames in the tabbed pane. Dragging the tab will only drag one dockable frame. If this flag is false, dragging title bar will just drag one dockable frame.

      Returns:
      true if all dockable frames in the tabbed pane will be dragged when draggin the title bar.

      setDragAllTabs

      public void setDragAllTabs(boolean dragAllTabs)
      Sets if dragging title bar will drag all dockable frames in the tabbed pane.

      Parameters:
      dragAllTabs -
      See Also:

      setFrameAvailable

      public void setFrameAvailable(java.lang.String name)
      Makes the frame available.

      Usually all dockable frames are added to DockingManager when application is started. However some frames may only be available under certain context. For example, palette window should only be available when editing a GUI form. In this case, you can set the palette to available when GUI form is active. Or else, set it to unavailble.

      Set the frame available will restore the last state of the frame when it is set to unavailable.

      Parameters:
      name - name of dockable frame

      setFrameUnavailable

      public void setFrameUnavailable(java.lang.String name)
      Makes the frame unavailable.

      Usually all dockable frames are added to DockingManager when application is started. However some frames may only be available under certain context. For example, palette window should only be available when editing a GUI form. In this case, you can set the palette to available when GUI form is active. Or else, set it to unavailble.

      Set the frame unavailable will hide the frame no matter what state it is. However the state will be remembered so that when later it was set to available, that state will be restored. When frame is unavailable, operations to that frame such as showFrame, hideFrame, etc, will have no effect.

      Parameters:
      name - name of dockable frame

      switchRootPaneContainer

      public void switchRootPaneContainer(javax.swing.RootPaneContainer rootContainer)
      Change the root pane container. The root pane container is set as a parameter in constructor of DockingManager. However if the content container is moved to another root pane container, you need to call this method to let DockingManager know the change.

      We suggest you call saveLayout to a known location before calling this method, then call loadLayout to load the saved layout back after calling to switchRootPaneContainer to make sure dockable frames are laid out correctly in the new root pane container.

      Parameters:
      rootContainer -

      handleEscapeKey

      setUndoLimit

      public void setUndoLimit(int limit)
      Set the maximum number of edits this UndoManager will hold. If edits need to be discarded to shrink the limit, they will be told to die in the reverse of the order that they were added.

      Parameters:
      limit -

      setShowInitial

      public void setShowInitial(boolean value)
      A client may specify that the docking layout is to be initialized without showing the window. In this case, the client is responsible for calling showInitial() the first time the window is to be shown. Default is true, show the window at the end of initial layout.

      Parameters:
      value -

      isShowInitial

      public boolean isShowInitial()
      A client may specify that the docking layout is to be initialized without showing the window. In this case, the client is responsible for calling showInitial() the first time the window is to be shown.

      showInitial

      public void showInitial()
      A client may specify that the docking layout is to be initialized without showing the window. In this case, the client is responsible for calling showInitial() the first time the window is to be shown.

      getDoubleClickAction

      public int getDoubleClickAction()
      Gets the action when user double clicks on the title bar of a dockable frame. It could be either DOUBLE_CLICK_TO_FLOAT (default) or DOUBLE_CLICK_TO_MAXIMIZE or DOUBLE_CLICK_NONE if you don't want to have any action associated with double click.

      Returns:
      the action of double click on title bar.

      setDoubleClickAction

      public void setDoubleClickAction(int doubleClickAction)
      Sets the action when user double clicks on the title bar of a dockable frame.

      Parameters:
      doubleClickAction - Either DOUBLE_CLICK_TO_FLOAT or DOUBLE_CLICK_TO_MAXIMIZE or DOUBLE_CLICK_NONE.

      getLayoutDirectory

      public java.lang.String getLayoutDirectory()
      Gets the directory that used for storing layout files. It is used only when setUsePref is false.

      Specified by:
      getLayoutDirectory in interface LayoutPersistence
      Returns:
      the directory so store layout files.

      setLayoutDirectory

      public void setLayoutDirectory(java.lang.String layoutDirectory)
      Sets the layout directory. Layout directory is used to store layout files only when setUsePref is false.

      Specified by:
      setLayoutDirectory in interface LayoutPersistence
      Parameters:
      layoutDirectory -

      isAutoDocking

      public boolean isAutoDocking()
      Auto docking means when a dockable frame is dragged, it will automatically attempt to dock to other docked frames. By default, this flag is true. If this flag is false, it will not try to dock thus every time you drag a docked dockable frame, it will became floating state. The only way to dock back is to click on toggle floating button.

      Returns:
      if auto docking is enabled.

      setAutoDocking

      public void setAutoDocking(boolean autoDocking)
      Auto docking means when a dockable frame is dragged, it will automatically attempt to dock to other docked frames. By default, this flag is true. If this flag is false, it will not try to dock thus every time you drag a docked dockable frame, it will became floating state. The only way to dock back is to click on toggle floating button.

      Parameters:
      autoDocking - if auto docking is enabled. Default is true.

      isSuspendTabStateChangeActivations

      public boolean isSuspendTabStateChangeActivations()

      isFocusDuringLoadLayout

      public boolean isFocusDuringLoadLayout()
      Accessor for the flag indicating whether focus should be requested for DockableFrames during load layout. (also implies activation, which happens when a subcomponent receives focus)

      Returns:
      if focus request is enabled during load layout

      setFocusDuringLayout

      public void setFocusDuringLayout(boolean doFocus)

      Parameters:
      doFocus - should focus requests be enabled during load layout

      isAllowRequestFocus

      public boolean isAllowRequestFocus()
      Because requesting focus may be restricted by the DockingManager during load layout, this method allows a DockableFrame to ask if it is allowed to request focus.

      Returns:
      Does the DockingManager allow a focus request at this time?

      removeExtraContexts

      getAllContexts

      Gets the all DockContexts in cache.

      Returns:
      a Map of all DockContexts.

      getAllowedDockSides

      public int getAllowedDockSides()
      Gets the allowed dock sides. The side values are defined in DockContext. The actual value returned is a OR of all possible dock sides. The possible dock sides are DockContext.DOCK_SIDE_NORTH, DockContext.DOCK_SIDE_SOUTH, DockContext.DOCK_SIDE_WEST, and DockContext.DOCK_SIDE_EAST. Or you can use combine values such as DockContext.DOCK_SIDE_HORIZONTAL, DockContext.DOCK_SIDE_VERTICAL or DockContext.DOCK_SIDE_ALL. Please note, DockContext.DOCK_SIDE_CENTER is not a valid value# By default, dragging a dockable frame to workspace is not allowed anyway# If you want to control it, you should use Workspace.setAcceptDockableFrame(boolean).

      This setting will only affect user dragging. For example, if you set the allowed dock sides to not allow north side, user won't be able to drag a dockable frame and put it to the north side of the main window or the north side of workspace area. However if a dockable frame's initial side is set to north, it will be put to north. So you as developer need to consciously avoid initial dock sides which you don't allow using this setting.

      Returns:
      allowed dock sides.

      setAllowedDockSides

      public void setAllowedDockSides(int allowedDockSides)
      Sets allowed dock sides.

      Parameters:
      allowedDockSides -
      See Also:
      {@link #getAllowedDockSides()}

      shouldVetoRemovingAllFrames

      public boolean shouldVetoRemovingAllFrames()
      Checks if the removeAllFrames() should be vetoed. This method works with shouldVetoHiding() method in dockable frame. You only need to use it when you override shouldVetoHiding() in your dockable frame implementations.

      When your application exits, you should call dockingManager.dispose(). However if you override shouldVetoHiding() in your dockable frame implementations, you need call this method first. If this method returns false, you proceed to dispose() method. If it returns true, you should stop the application exiting process.

      Returns:
      true if the removing all frames process should be vetoed.

      isHideFloatingFramesOnSwitchOutOfApplication

      public boolean isHideFloatingFramesOnSwitchOutOfApplication()
      We can hide floating frames when we switch to a different DockingManager. Do we do the same when we switch to a different application?

      setHideFloatingFramesOnSwitchOutOfApplication

      public void setHideFloatingFramesOnSwitchOutOfApplication(boolean newValue)
      Turn hiding floating frames when we switch to a different application on and off.
